text: every summer since I was born I went to
my grandparents house on Cape Cod the
grandfather was the head of the music
department at Harvard my mother's music
teacher at my elementary school my
autism cellist
they were definitely responsible for
making music a day-to-day sort of
experience for us growing up but I don't
ever think when I was a child or even a
teenager that I even occurred to me that
I would get involved in music in a
professional capacity I was sort of
feeling confused as one often does when
they get out of college so I got my own
crappy mic and unearthed that old guitar
and that's when I started making music
but it was really truly like for myself
like a sort of cathartic release I mean
I spent about a year and a half just for
diddling around on it and then
eventually got up the courage to share
it with friends and that's eventually
what became the first I left out
really hard to boil down life to like
four or five moments that were the most
inspiring things that sort of define why
I'm creative it's so many it's like I
thought it's basically everything it's
just a lot of it had to do with just
touring and meeting people and
experiencing the world and traveling and
school and my parents and their split
you know life experiences it's like
there's so many I think failure and
frustration and friction are key to the
creative process especially with
collaboration I mean if we were able to
come together every time and magically
happily create an album in a couple
months without fail I would think that
something was wrong it's I think every
time we finish an album
question that always comes up is are we
gonna be able to do it again well
everyone's energy aligned and will we be
able to synergize as cheesy assassins
it's very important that everyone's
energized
you
